title: 1968 at 50: Architecture, Art, and Cultures of Resistance around the Globe
xlist: Same As: ARCH 3285, section 01
description: To mark the fiftieth anniversary of the watershed year 1968, the seminar travels back to a moment when a range of struggles for social justice—from the antiwar movement, to civil rights, women’s rights, and gay liberation movements, among others—occupied public spaces and campuses across the globe, including here at Yale. The seminar focuses on the relationship between artistic practices and the group formations that came into being during these years in a transnational framework. It examines readings, publications, artworks, ephemera, and actions by radical political organizations, from the Black Panthers to West German Red Army Faction (RAF), as well as counterculture groups, from the Situationist International (SI) to radical Italian architectural groups Archizoom and Superstudio. Classes, held at Beinecke Library, center on archival material concerning 1960s political and artistic counterculture. Each session is devoted to a different city, including Paris, Tokyo, New York, Florence, New Haven, Mexico City, London, Prague, Berlin, and Berkeley. The goal is not to commemorate 1968, but to reconsider its afterlives and to examine its traces in the present.
